content:
I feel like in many of my projects it's common to cc @rust-lang/teamname to get wider input in a github thread. This is pretty great, but what i've found is that it ends up happening pretty often and ends up subscribing me to more threads than I want to be on.

There are some cases where you actually do have to ping the entire team (when you want approval for something, etc), but sometimes when you "just want wider input" the better thing to do is to start a Zulip thread. It's also a better platform for such discussions in general.

I wonder if there's benefit in e.g. having something like @triagebot zulip-thread <topic name> so that it's super easy to create zulip threads that link back to the issue (and ideally duplicate the text of your comment after the @triagebot command), and get a comment on the issue linking to the zulip thread. I feel like this would be super useful but I'm not sure which bot to plug it into.

cc @Joshua Nelson
This would be super helpful :) I think triagebot is the right place, @simulacrum is trying to move highfive's functionality there.
It needs a team name somewhere though.
@rustbot zulip libs Should we do X?
yeah, triagebot/rustbot are the same bot, and this would fit will there, probably not too hard to add (it already has basically all the zulip API and github processing you'd need for this)
@Josh Triplett probably a channel name but yeah
actually we could support both having team names and full channel names
would someone have time for trying out an implementation? I may be able to make time but I wouldn't be able to test it
I think if it's going to be widely useful we shouldn't ask people to know Zulip channel names for each team.
And we'd want to make a stream for incoming requests from GitHub.
@Josh Triplett right, that's why I meant having both, you can create-stream libs foo but you can _also_ create-stream #t-libs/foobar foo
We typically test such things in production, fwiw, so I wouldn't be too worried about that aspect
